title: BiOnIC: A Catalog of User Interactions with Biomedical Ontologies

author: Maulik R. Kamdar, School of Medicine, Stanford University

segmentation: Thank you all for coming to my presentation.
It's always.
Back to have it in the last session, but I hope I can keep you excited and interested.
My name is Malik and I'm going to present Bionica catalog of user interactions with biomedical ontologies.
This was work done in collaboration with Simon Walk who is your in the audience and under Mark Nielsen Slab at Stanford University.
So some of the to get you motivated about user interactions also, especially in the context of biomedical ontologies and generally in biomedical ontologies.
I would like to highlight the benefits of analyzing this user interactions and for different stakeholders.
For example, if you are an ontology engineer, you may want to identify exploration and querying patterns.
You may want to understand ontology usage and reuse and also you may want to prune unwanted classes and relations if you are ontology.
Pozza Tori maintainers.
You may want to categorize or user behaviors and classify different users into different groups.
You may want to develop intelligent interfaces like based on the user group like given a set of classes.

What is the next class the user is going to access and maybe provide better website interfaces for that and you may want to also provide targeted recommendations based on the set of classes that a user has already already browsed or queried and if you are a domain expert and you know where quesa biomedical researcher, you may want to identify temporal research trends.
Classes which are frequently accessed, browsed or queried.
So this talk is about the catalog that we have published, which is the bounding catalog of user interactions.
And given a set of biomedical ontologies, we have published several different types of datasets that I will talk more about in the South.
I'd.
So this datasets work your generated from the bio portal repository and Bio portal.
For those who don't know, it's like the world's most comprehensive repository of biomedical ontologies and till last week it had like around 655 ontologies.
And there are several ontologies which are like browsed or queried by more than 10,000 users in a given month.

To give an idea like that is like so Mad City which is like one of the most popular on teologi aura terminology in the biomedical domain and it has like around 300,000 class more than 300,000 classes.
And it is like browsed, say for example in March or February by more than 10,000 users, and it is often considered or it's branded as the global language of health care.
And in biorepository you have got like different kinds of interfaces like one of the web interface where you can actually visualize this particular ontology.
The archical structure of the different classes in this ontology.
And you can navigate the logical structure and know more about a given class.
And you can also programmatically query the content in the bio portal repository using the recently released Bioportal API in 2013.

So the way we generated the data set from the bio portal repository was we took the Apache access logs and we took the access logs for the bio portal website from 2013 to 2017 till the mid 2016 and we also took the API logs from 2013 to mid 2016 and we've removed robot calls or those made by like web spiders who tried to index bioportal etc and we removed invalid request either made by the user.
Or made using say for example automated Logic's request and we normalize all ontology identifiers.

An class I rise to a particular version and we're using the January 2015 version for the for the All the ontologies and we also have like an inclusion criteria for the catalog like so we only are currently generating the data sets for ontologies that reuse classes from other ontologies, either using by importing the different IR eyes or either mapping them to a common concept unique identifier.
And they are maybe there.

These classes are reused by other ontologies in the bar portal repository and we also like have like those only those ontologies which have like a minimum of 10 unique users via web UI and API who accepts these ontologies.
So we generate two types of datasets.
One is the class that is fixed data set for each class in each ontology.
We generate the following attributes like we generate access attributes which are like the total number of IP requests that are made to.

To query or browse a particular class and also the number of unique IP requests that are made to query your browser particular class using the web UI or the API, we have a set of reuse attributes which are like the number of ontologies that reuse this particular class and we have a set of structural attributes in the ontology which is like the number of parent child.
Sibling classes are given.
Class has an.
What is the maximum depth that the class is located in?
The ontological your key from the root node of the ontology.

We also generate a separate second type of data set which is the user interaction sequences data set and given two ontologies and you're like, visualize them as a directed acyclic graph, and different classes are labeled randomly and their color according to the depth from the root node of the ontology and you have got a particular user who browses a particular class and I've gotta live screenshot going on from the bioportal repository where he's actually browsing this ontologies and navigating down the ontological you rocketry.
So he explores the different classes down the hierarchy, then decides to go up back.
The Archean probably uses the mappings to explore a similar class in a separate ontology and yours.
For example, the National Cancer Institute, the hours, and similarly tries to navigate the classes in the in that particular ontology down the hierarchy tree.
So we generate the user sequences by organizing them for different ontologies.

For example your the user is accessing two different ontologies, but we only we create two separate in sequences and these are like ordered according to the way they interact with the ontology classes.
And finally we also like anonymize the different sequences datasets.
We take two anonymization step because it's user data we lose all the IP addresses and we generate.
Some random user IDs which are unique based on the random string and random integer combination and Moreover we encode these identifiers using the SHA 224 hash algorithm.
And finally we also convert the timestamps to relative timestamps.
Sorry, absolute timestamps to relative timestamps with respect to the first interaction.
The particular user makes with the buyer bottle repository and then the all the subsequent interactions are then subtract are subtracted with respect to that first interaction time.
So you will just see a sequence of numbers.
In seconds.
And we publish this data sets in two formats.
One is the tab separated value format and the other is using RDF and we use the Bionic schema to model this different datasets.
We reuse some of the popular standards such as costs, provenance, ontology, and the data catalog vocabulary.
In this particular schema and we have published this datasets using TSV, an RDF HTT files.
For those of you do not know, HTT HTT is the Super compressed version of RDF.

It stands for header, dictionary, triples and you can always convert them to normal RDF in N triples or total format using the software that HD provides and you can upload this security files or this RDF files into a sparkle triplestore triple pattern FRAGMENTE server and you can actually, as we're trying to say, also like conserve the different IR eyes.
You can also query the bioportal sparkle endpoint in conjunction with this RDF datasets.
So for example, if you have got a query, get me all the classes that.
Talk about Melanoma and I also want to know what are the number of times a particular number of times this Melanoma classes are accessed using the web UI or the API.

Some statistics of this data set, so we have got like around 5.4 million class requests which we have refined made by 1 million unique agents using the web for the web UI and for the Bio Portal API, we have refined 67.2 million class requests and made by 200 and 5000 unique agents and this has been done for 205 by 255 biomedical ontologies.
And we have not tried to threshold that.
I'm like what what should be considered the time of interaction to be a sequence.
For example, a user access bioportal at a particular day and then one year later he comes back to access Bioportal again.
But we consider them to be number one whole sequence.
We leave it up to the user of this particular catalog to decide what threshold he or she wants to use in his research.

And as you can see there maybe like around 8 two thirty classes, depending on whether you are looking at the web UI sequences or API sequences, the number of unique classes are generally around 3:00 to 10:00, and the time taken to or the time maybe and may vary between like one hour or for example in the API.
It's like around .0 four .001 hour.
We also provide a web application to visualize this different datasets.
The statistics datasets and the sequences datasets, and we turn the web application's vision or visualizing ontology interactions it has got.
Different perspectives to visualize the different, different perspective.

To visualize the data sets, and I apologize for the colors, I tried using my laptop and the PDF but it's not working, but you can actually access the vision application using the link provided, so we provide like different scatterplots to visualize and it's very interactive so the user can select the your of the data set as well as which feature he wants to visualize on the X axis Y axis and also called change the shape in the.
Color of the different scatter points.
He can also use the word cloud to visualize the labels of the classes that were significantly accessed using the API or the web UI, or in a particular time.
We also incorporate the Polygon to visualization and it looks much more pretty than the one that on the screen.

But the idea behind the Polygon to visualization and this is currently under review in the Journal of Web Semantics, is we transform the directed acyclic graph structure of an ontology to a polygonal shape where sorry.
Uh, do a polygonal shape where the different classes are look over abstracted based on the maximum depth.
They're located from the root of the ontology and we do the similar thing for user sequences that we had generated in the catalog.
For example, there are three sets of users who are accessing this ontology, and they're created into their own distinct polygons and overlaid over the ontological Polygon Polygon.
To give an example, if you've got the cabbie ontology of.
Chemical compounds and you've got the cabin here are key.
Then you can generate the Polygon to visualization for this for web UI datasets or API sequences by transforming this into a polygonal shape, so the red indicates the ontology structure.
The blue indicates interaction sequences and also we provide like visualize small circles to indicate single clicks.
These are those users who just like Access Bio portal for one class and tell you, and they never come back.
Some of the applications that I would like to talk in the last three minutes that I have in the four Bionic envision.
And this and you can develop more applications using it.
These are just like some of the ideas you can like.
Try to identify certain classes which are more significantly browsed or queried in a particular year.

In 2015, such as cellular fragmentation, cell growth, pigmentation, etc.
And some classes which are more proud into rows in 2000.
16 about hydrolase activity are in a synthetic process, etc.
There were also interface influences which we can visualize using the scatter plots.
There are certain classes which are browser queried significantly more, so this is the experimental factor ontology.
You can see that there are some classes that are like female reproductive system and army Switcher.
Browse like more than 100 times by 100 unique web users, but they're never queried using the API.

And then there are dysmorphic syndrome and night blindness which are like varied more than 1000 times using the API by 1000 unique users, but they're never browsing the web web UI, so this obviously requires some domain experts to identify why this is the case.
And finally, using the Polygon to visualization, you can identify like you can like, summarize the sequences and series like some some some patterns that may emerge out of this.

For example, there are certain classes the Polygon to visualization of the gene ontology, and you can see that there are certain classes in the lower levels of the year are key, like around 100 classes where there are no users who browse it using the bar portal repository.
This may be an artifact of the indented tree visualization where you need to click each class and go down the.
There are key and it's very, very difficult for the particular user, or it may be just that the users don't find this class is more important and you can see there are like low.

The lower levels don't have any blue polygons and sometimes you may also see triangular polygons which which is again maybe an artifact of the web UI, access plugins triangular polygons generally indicate when a user is trying to browse the parent class and two child classes or vice versa.

And one more application that Simon did, and this was published in www.in 27 this year is he tried to model the user behaviors using Markov chains and try to get cluster them and identified seven different categories about different ways the users explore and this was done on a raw, unprocessed version of the catalog, but it's still very important and you can see there are class explorers, ontology tree explorers etc and.

An modularization.
Don't wrap up.
We published the bionic category catalog of user interactions with biomedical ontologies and we developed.
We also present a vision web application and with that I would like to complete my talk and.
I would like technology with the lab and the BMI PhD program.
